DIRECTORY of Northern & Southern Saskatchewan 1953 - 54 Published by OVERGARD DIRECTORIES Regina, Sask. A Dependable Service: By special request we have listed both northern and southern Saskatchewan towns, villages, hamlets and country post offices in alphabetical order. To give this additional service it has been necessary to compile two volumes. The extra coverage for our Regina subscribers include the Yorkton and Melville districts with listings of Yorkton and Melville, including house numbers and occupations. East to the Manitoba border and south to Weybum and Estevan. The Moose Jaw district is covered as far south as Assiniboia and west to Swift Current. The main line villages and hamlets to the Alberta border. The provincial electoral districts of Souris, Estevan, Weyburn, Bengough, Notukeu, Willowbunch, Shaunavon, Maple Creek and Swift Current have not been covered in these volumes. Farm write-ups are listed under separate index. Alphabetical index from Meadow Lake to Zenon Park. Address Correspondence to Overgard Directories, 1849 Cornwall St., Regina, Sask. 'If cue The publishers wish to take this opportunity of thanking the advertisers who by their liberal patronage, made possible the printing and publication of these up-to-date and comprehensive Directories. A perusal of the adver¬ tisements to be found in these volumes will prove of value to many readers. Sincere thanks is also extended to all those who generously tendered assist¬ ance in the immense task of gathering the necessary information required in compiling these volumes. This issue of the Saskatchewan Business Directories was compiled by the publishers from information gathered or supplied to them, and nothing has been taken or copied from other publications of a similar nature. Included in this volume are many items of interest not to be found elsewhere, and care has been taken to ensure the correctness of all information printed herein. In a publication of this size, errors or omissions may creep in, and no responsibility will be accepted by the publishers for any such errors or omissions. Population 2,100 A P.O. and Incorporated Town in S. 25-26, Twp. 59. R. 17, W3rd, in North Battleford Dom. Elec. Dist. Meadow Lake Prov. Elec. Dist., Battleford Land Reg. and Jud. Dist., Local Imp. Dist No 588, on the C.P.R. 110 miles North of North Battleford on No. 4 Highway. Has C.P. tele¬ graph and express, Sask. Govt, local and^ long distance telephones. Anglican, United, Lutheran, Christian Missionary Alliance and R.C. Churches. Good public and high schools. Meadow Lake Hos¬ pital; all graduate nurses and excellent medical staff; equipped with up-to-date operating room, isolation ward and nurses’ home in connection. RESOURCES: Lumbering; wholesale distribu¬ tors for fish to Eastern Canada and American markets. Ranching; fur farming; private mink farms and an abundance of wild fur-bearing animals. This is an excellent wheat growing district, also The Hunter’s Paradise of the North; partridge, grouse, prairie chicken, the Canada goose and wild ducks. Big game hunting includes moose, deer and caribou. MAYOR—A. P. Weber. TOWN CLERK & TREASURER—J. W. Heartwell. CONCILLORS—W. W. Grant, J. R. Gibson, F. Langlechner, D. P. Revitt, Arthur. Porter, M. S. EDNA McINNIS President Manageress 10 OVERGARD DIRECTORIES—NORTHERN SASKATCHEWAN MELFORT SASKATCHEWAN The Hub of the Carrot River Valley y> POPULATION—3,000 Served by the two large transcontinental railway systems. The C.P.R., with seven branches radiating through the rich and fertile Carrot River Valley, making it an ideal point for distributing for wholesale and retail houses. To care for this we have fifty-five passenger trains arriv¬ ing and departing each week from the Union Depot. In addition to railway service, we also enjoy a transcontinental bus service, and the finest grass airport in Western Canada. IMPORTANT TRADING CENTRE THE TOWN OF MELFORT is the trading centre for the famous Carrot River Valley, comprising approximately 5,000 square miles of the choicest agricultural land in Western Canada producing annually millions of bushels of wheat and other cereal grains, as well as an enormous value in livestock products. MODERN COMMUNITY MELFORT IS A MODERN TOWN in every respect, having a 24-hour electric light and power service, and the largest automatic rural telephone exchange in Canada. It has an abundance of good water with a reservoir capacity of 120 million gallons; sewer system and up-to-date disposal plant. New school, new Memorial Rink and Civic Centre under construc¬ tion. JUDICIAL CENTRE IT IS THE JUDICIAL CENTRE of the district and is located in what is known as the park area of the province. FIFTY-BED HOSPITAL MELFORT HAS A FIFTY-BED HOSPITAL which is completely modern with the very latest equipment. It is well adapted to the needs of the community it serves. New 30-bed wing under construction. EXCELLENT ANNUAL FAIR MELFORT HAS ALSO one of the best Class “B” fairs in Western Can¬ ada, well equipped with large stock barns and a grandstand with a seating capacity of over 5,000. There are many other outstanding features which make it the “Hub of the North” For further information write to MELFORT BOARD OF TRADE S. B. Caskey, President. W. W. Aikenhead, Secretary. OVERGARD DIRECTORIES—NORTHERN SASKATCHEWAN 11 MELFORT, SASK. (Population 3,000) A P.O. in S. 7, Twp. 45, R. 18, W. 2nd, in Mel- fort Dom. Elect. Dist., Melfort Prov. Elec. Dist., Prince Albert Land Reg. Dist. and Melfort Jud. Dist., Mun. Nos. 428 and 429, on the C.N. and C.P. railways with seven lines running into Melfort, which is 190 miles north of Regina and 118 miles northeast of Saskatoon. Has C.N. and C.P. telegraph and express, Sask. Govt, local and long distance telephones with the distinction of having the largest automatic rural telephone centre in the west and possibly the largest in the Dominion. Is the judicial centre, with resi¬ dent judge and sheriff’s office. Dominion Experi¬ mental Farm two miles south. Has Anglican, United, Presbyterian, Roman Catholic, Church of the Nazarene, Apostolic Mission, Holiness Move¬ ment and Salvation Army, excellent public schools and collegiate with complete commercial course in connection. Lady Minto Hospital, established in 1907 as an outpost hospital with a donation from Lady Minto through the Victorian Order of Nurses, the business men of the community furn¬ ishing the balance of the capital. The hospital is now a corporate body with board elected an¬ nually. A new wing of solid concrete construc¬ tion was added in 1937, ten private wards in individual color schemes and furnished with the latest modern hospital furnishings, were made possible through donations by private parties. Equipped with latest X-ray and operating equip¬ ment, staffed with experienced graduate nurses, this fifty-bed hospital is a credit to the com¬ munity. The Grain Growers’ Co-op Assn., Ltd., is one of the largest co-operative branches in the Province. The Carrot River Valley Co-Op Mar¬ keting Association, Ltd., do an extensive busi¬ ness throughout the district. There are three elevators, three lumber yards, planing mill, flour mill.
